definition: to stir up emotion/to arouse sympathy/moving
to fan into a flame/to incite

sentences.english: Afterwards, sensationalism places its root in Hong Kong media.
sentences.chinese: 從該時開始，煽情主義在香港植根。

sentences.english: Palin adopted a touchy-feely tone during the hour long interview. Photograph: Reuters
sentences.chinese: 在長達一小時的採訪中，佩林表現地頗爲煽情。

sentences.english: Discourse while not sensational, but every word Rugu Sui, knock on people's minds.
sentences.chinese: 話語雖不煽情，但卻字字入骨髓，敲人心。

sentences.english: For anytime, being over sensational will lead to being affectedly unconventional.
sentences.chinese: 因爲任何時候，過分的煽情都會導致矯情。

sentences.english: However, the most-poignant moment was when he thanked his father, Joel De La Hoya Sr.
sentences.chinese: 然而，最煽情的時刻莫過於感謝他的父親老徳拉霍亞。

sentences.english: My family is not big on emotional goodbyes.
sentences.chinese: 我的家人不太擅長煽情式的離別。

sentences.english: I know: this sounds like so much motivational public speaker mumbo jumbo.
sentences.chinese: 我知道，這聽着像煽情演說家騙人的鬼話。

sentences.english: You may wonder, didnt I say anything that provocative.
sentences.chinese: 你會感到困惑，難道我說的每一句話都那麼煽情嗎？

definition: to move to tears (of a story)/tear-provoking (gas)/lacrimogen
silly talk or "mo lei tau" (Cantonese), genre of humor emerging from Hong Kong late in the 20th century
